As X have Indicated, his political rise was even more spectacular
than his business career. He was first chosen secretary of the
parliamentary finance and treasury commission, in October of 1946 he
became undersecretary of finance in the second Be Gasper* cabinet, and
in 1947 he was appointed finance minister.
it was in this period that Pella came under the wing of his fellow
Piedmontese, Luigi Einaudi, who then was budget minister. Einaudi was a
lifelong Liberal and Pella a Christian Democrat, but they got on famously
with regard to Italy's financial problems.
Einaudi was elected the first regular President of the Italian
republic in 1948. On his recommendation Be Crasperi appointed Pella to
replace him as treasury and budget minister. Pella has held this job —
which makes him a kind of czar over the Italian economy -- ever since.
Until President Einaadi summoned him in August and asked him to
form a government, Pella was chiefly known in Italy for the policy known
as the “defense of the lira.11 This was a hard boiled, hard currency,
anti-inflation policy.
Its impact on parliament was Coftoned to some extent by the calm
manner and moderate language with which Pella explained and defended it.
3ut the “Pella line,* as it is known, brought some grumbling in the
country and some criticism as being too rigid. In 1951 the policy seemed
to be in serious danger, but Pella threatened to resign and, in the end.
Be Gasperl backed him up.
